_prev_prog_3.Description:
P4701



The P4701 process produces the regulated chemical as a byproduct off gas which is collected in the vent system.  The gas is captured and compressed into a liquid, stored and shipped offsite. Ambient sensors continuously monitor for leaks. The process is computer controlled.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan Executive Summary SI Group Inc. Newport Operations

 

SI Group, Inc. is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety. This commitment is reinforced by compliance with the OSHA PSM requirements through a comprehensive accidental release prevention program in place that covers design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the process at our facility.      



SI Group Inc. is highly committed to decreasing the likelihood that a release will occur, but unforeseeably if such a release does occur, our highly trained emergency response personnel in coordination with the Cocke County Emergency Management Agency will control and mitigate the effects of the release.  At SI Group Inc., control is implemented by applying "six layers of protection."  



1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies.

The first layer of protection is comprised of our employees who are highly trained to utilize the distributive control system to safely operate the process.  The second line of defense is implementation of our Mechanical Integrity Program which complies with the OSHA PSM rules and ensures integrity and preventative maintenance on the equipment.  Thirdly, Hazard Reviews through HAZOP Process Hazard Analysis have been conducted by examining all process procedures and equipment. The process controls and devices such as relief control valves and flares, make up the fourth layer of protection.  Backing up the controls is the monitoring system, which includes continual data readout by operators in the control room. A sixth layer of protection is provided by our Emergency Response team, which has at its disposal equipment sufficient to control a release. 

The Cocke County Fire Department is familiar with our facility and can provide prompt backup.     



2. The Stationary Source and Regulated Substance Handled.

Our facility's primary activities encompasses organic chemical syn

thesis. The RMP regulated chemical at our facility is 2-Methylpropene (CAS 115-11-7). This chemical is a byproduct of the chemical production process and is more commonly called isobutylene.



3. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



The facility is operated to comply with OSHA PSM 29 CFR 1910.119, which includes designs and mechanical integrity based on ASME standards. The operating procedures specifically address release prevention of the substance according to OSHA PSM. The site is also subject to control requirements under the EPA Title V Air Permit Program. The 2-Methylpropene storage and transfer facilities are designed according to NFPA 58 (Liquefied Petroleum Gas Code). Pressure vessels are designed and tested according to State of Tennessee regulations on boilers and pressure vessels. 



Process Safety Information.

SI Group Inc. maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating safety information, operating parameters, and equipment designs.



Process Hazard Analysis

SI Group Inc. has conducted and will revalidate as needed, comprehensive studies to ensure hazards are identified and controlled. The methodology used to carry out the analyses are HAZOP and what if checklists. In addition, based on the PHA findings, further evaluations are conducted using a Layer Of Protection Analysis (LOPA) to determine if additional controls are needed per a Safety Instrumented System (SIS). The methods are based on the IEC 61511 Functional safety -Safety instrumented systems for the process industry 2003-01. 



Operating Procedures

The procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  Consequences of deviation and emergency procedures are included.



Training

The SI Group Inc. emergency response personnel are organized into teams with an Incident Commander per each shift. The p

ersonnel are all trained as "Hazmat Technicians Level".  In addition, the team members are trained as a Fire Brigade with additional hours of training.  Refresher fire brigade and hazmat training according to OSHA HAZWOPER is conducted each year.



Mechanical Integrity

SI Group Inc. conducted detailed pre-startup mechanical integrity and continues to carry out highly documented maintenance checks on such equipment as pressure vessels, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps. 



Management of Change

Written procedures are in place at SI Group Inc. to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures. All employees are trained and participate in the Management of Change system.



Pre-startup 

Before startup of the process or changes in the process, formal safety reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing the equipment in operation.



Compliance Audits

SI Group Inc. conducts audits to determine that the provisions under PSM and RMP are implemented. These audits will be repeated at least every three years. SI Group has been recertified in 2016 to the Tennessee Star VPP Program. SI Group Newport has been a member of this exclusive group since 2013. 



Employee Participation

Employees participated in the PHA and pre-startup safety reviews as well as contributed to modifying the design and procedures for the safest operation. Employees are encouraged to participate per team meetings and safety meetings.  Annually a letter is distributed asking for employees' continued input.



Contractors

A detailed written program for approving, hiring, orienting, and evaluating contractors on the potential hazards in the facility is implemented at the SI Group Inc. plant. In the orientation contractors are trained in their role in emergencies.



4. Five-year Accident History



The SI Group Inc. plant started up in August 2005. There have b

een no emergency releases.





5. Emergency Response Plan



The emergency response plan is written in the format of the EPA's "One Plan" or Integrated Contingency Plan. The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including rescue and follow up first aid or medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies, and the public. Included are specific procedures for the RMP regulated substance, 2-Methylpropene. The emergency equipment is regularly inspected and tested.



The Cocke County Emergency Management Agency Director, local police, local hospital and the Cocke County Fire Chief have been provided a copy of the plan and are familiar with the plant site. The Cocke County Fire Chief and the State Fire Marshall have also reviewed the NFPA 58 Fire Safety Analysis for storage of the 2-Methylpropene. 



6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety



An improvement to the fire protection system by adding additional sprinkler heads to provide cooling water for vertical steel columns is completed. Building 22 Control Room Fire Suppression System has been activated. Monitor nozzles have been upgrade and new fire suppression foam has been added to inventory.
